title: How can we get out of a motorhome payment that we cant afford without filling bankruptcy or the lender putting a lean on our hom
question: We still owe $100,000 and have been paying on it for 10 yrs. The re-sale value in now $40,000. we are retired now and it is very hard on us to make the $1000.00 a month payment on a fixed income.We have money in savings and own our home. Is their a way of getting out of this loan without them taking our savings or putting a lean on our home?
answers:
We would need a lot more facts to give you a precise answer. The fact that you say you own your home makes me think that chapter 7 is not an option unless you actually mean you have a home that's really the bank's because you still have a mortgage.

Go see a good bankruptcy attorney to discuss your options or lack thereof with respect to bankruptcy.

In the alternative, your lender may be willing to negotiate the debt you'll still owe after voluntarily returning the motor home. Some creditors are willing to accept less than the amount you owe, but many factors are involved, and you should get good legal counsel on the benefits, consequences, and risks associated with going that route.

This is a very serious situation, but you may have several options.

I concur with the advice offered by my colleagues and add: BK is not a DIY project. Consult with a BK lawyer in your area. Some of us offer a free case analysis by phone or in person. Take us up on it. Properly structured, you can return the RV and protect the equity in your home and get a fresh financial start.

If you surrender the motor home, the lender will sell the motor coach, and then apply the sale proceeds to your note. You will then get sued for the deficiency. It will be a very large deficiency claim, probably over $65,000. You should consult a bankruptcy attorney about filing a Chapter 7 case. You can surrender the motor coach in the Chapter 7 case, and walk away from liability on the note. Go see a bankruptcy attorney ASAP.

If you signed a legal contract, then it is binding upon you. The lender has rights to pursue you for the unpaid balance if you default, as defined in the terms of the contract you signed.
That is a lot of money, to me, anyway. I would consult with a bankruptcy attorney and think long and hard before rejecting the idea of a fresh start, which a bankruptcy can provide.

Your exemption statutes may very well allow you keep your savings and your home, depending upon the circumstances. Find an attorney on AVVO to consult with.

But no, once you sign on the dotted line, you are on the hook and at the mercy of your creditor.
